clinical_study.brief_title: Promotion of Emotional Well-being in Hospitalized Cancer Patients by Virtual Reality
clinical_study.official_title: A Brief Psychological Intervention Using Virtual Reality for the Promotion of Emotional Well-being in Hospitalized Cancer Patients

brief_summary.textblock: The aim of this study is to analyze the effect of a brief psychological intervention supported by Information and Communication Technologies, on the subjective well-being of hospitalized cancer patients. Participants are randomly assigned to one of 2 conditions: Intervention condition (4 Virtual reality sessions) and Control condition (waiting list control group).

primary_outcome.measure: The Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS) (Zigmond & Snaith, 1983; adapted version of Tejero, Guimerá, Farré & Peri, 1986)

secondary_outcome.description: Subjective mood change after each intervention session.

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analog Scale: Emotional State. Change from pre to post session.
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of general mood, joy, sadness, anxiety, relax and vigor (7-point Likert scale)

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analog Scale: Physical Discomfort. Change from pre to post session.
secondary_outcome.description: Presence of pain, fatigue and physical discomfort (11-point Likert scale)

secondary_outcome.measure: Visual Analog Scale: Satisfaction with the Session Scale.
secondary_outcome.description: Level of pleasantness and perceived usefulness of each session (11-point Likert scale)

secondary_outcome.measure: Satisfaction with Intervention Scale (adapted version of Borkovec and Nau's, 1972)
secondary_outcome.description: Assesses satisfaction, recommendation, utility and discomfort (11-point Likert scale)

other_outcome.measure: The Brief Illness Perception Questionnaire (BIPQ) (Broadbent et al., 2006)
other_outcome.description: This instrument has 9 items aimed to evaluate the cognitive and emotional representation of the illness (consequences, timeline, personal control, treatment control, identity, concern, emotional response, illness coherence and causes).
Patient has 6 alternatives of illness meaning (Loss, threat, challenge, blame-others, blame-self and opportunity). In addition to these alternatives, participant can add any other personal meaning.

arm_group.description: The entire intervention is composed by four 30 minutes sessions along 1 week. Its focus is on the promotion of well-being by the use of two virtual environments ("Emotional Parks" and "Walk through Nature"). These environments allow participants to involve in different exercises (working with self statements, videos, images, slow breathing, focus on the present exercises) with the purpose of increase positive emotional states.

Participants receive the medical treatment deliver by the hospital. They fulfill several questionnaires at two moments (pre and post 1 week after). After this, they have the possibility to receive the psychological intervention.

intervention.description: Participants receive two sessions oriented to joy and two focused on relax. In the first 2 sessions patients can choose the environment ("Emotional Parks" or "Walk through Nature") and in the following ones participants visit the alternate environments.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- adults with any cancer diagnosis
- hospitalized for at least 1 week
- Karnofsky functional state ≥50
- life expectancy ≥2 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- serious psychopathology
- cognitive impairment
